title: R42644
content: The Administration requested $39.510 billion for DHS in FY2013, a slight decrease from the previous year. The Senate Committee on Appropriations approved a net discretionary appropriation of $39.514 million for DHS, excluding funds for overseas operations and disaster relief. The Senate-reported bill provided slightly less funding than the Administration's request for DHS in FY2013. The House passed H.R. 5855 with amendments, resulting in a net discretionary appropriation of $39,114 million. The President signed H.J.Res. 117 into law as a continuing resolution through March 27, 2013. The FY2013 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, signed into law as P.L. 113-6, provided $39.646 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for the Department of Homeland Security. After across-the-board cuts, $38.348 billion was available for DHS to use. The FY2013 Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, P.L. 113-6, allocated $39.646 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority for the Department of Homeland Security, with $38.348 billion available after across-the-board cuts. Funding details were sourced from various congressional reports, budget documents, and post-sequestration operating plans. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 (P.L. 107-296) transferred functions, funding, and personnel of 22 agencies to the new Department of Homeland Security. Appropriations for DHS are organized into five titles, covering various offices and agencies such as Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Transportation Security Administration, and Federal Emergency Management Agency. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 transferred functions, funding, and personnel to the Department of Homeland Security. Appropriations for DHS are organized into five titles, with additional titles sometimes added for special issues in the annual appropriations bills. The maximum budget authority is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process. The 302(a) allocations are discretionary totals available to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations for annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees then allocate the 302(b) discretionary funds among their subcommittees for each bill, with any total above the ceiling subject to a point of order. Adjustments to 302(b) allocations can be made during the year as bills progress towards final enactment. The FY2012 appropriations bills were the first affected by the Budget Control Act, which established spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013. The Budget Control Act (BCA) established nonsecurity spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013, with separate caps for security spending. The BCA allows for adjustments to cover funding for overseas contingency operations, emergency spending, disaster relief, and health care fraud and abuse. The levels set by the BCA became the basis for enforcement in the Senate and the House. The Budget Control Act (BCA) established spending caps for FY2012 and FY2013, with separate caps for security spending. The BCA required a deficit reduction plan to be enacted by January 15, 2012, triggering automatic spending cuts when not met. The sequestration process involved across-the-board spending cuts at the account and program level. The American Taxpayer Relief Act (ATRA) made significant changes on January 2, 2013. The American Taxpayer Relief Act (ATRA) made significant changes to the Budget Control Act (BCA) procedures in FY2013. The joint committee sequester date was delayed to March 1, 2013, with a $24 billion reduction in the dollar amount. President Obama ordered the sequester implementation, with sequestration applied at the program, project, and activity level. The post-sequestration numbers are derived from the FY2013 DHS operating plan. The report only focuses on resources provided through P.L. 113-6, not P.L. 113-2. Sections 3001 and 3004 of P.L. 113-6 aim to align budget authority with spending limits. DHS faces a 0.1% across-the-board cut in the "security" category to meet spending limits. The Office of Management and Budget determines if limits are exceeded. Section 3004 of P.L. 113-6 includes two separate across-the-board rescissions for nonsecurity and security budget authority to avoid exceeding spending limits. OMB calculated additional rescissions needed for DHS and other agencies. Funding for Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terror and disaster relief under the Budget Control Act are not subject to these cuts. Tables in the report show DHS's initial allocations for FY2013. DHS's appropriations process for FY2013 involved adjustments based on three justifications outlined in the BCA: emergency spending, overseas contingency operations, and disaster relief. OMB determined a $11,779 million allowable adjustment for disaster relief, fully exercised with $6,400 million from pre-sequestration resources through the FEMA Disaster Relief Fund in P.L. 113-6. The FY2013 DHS appropriations process involved adjustments based on three justifications outlined in the BCA. OMB determined a $11,779 million allowable adjustment for disaster relief, fully exercised with $6,400 million from pre-sequestration resources through the FEMA Disaster Relief Fund in P.L. 113-6. The final DHS appropriations legislation included in Division D of P.L. 113-6 prior to sequestration impact. The Administration proposed a 0.5% pay increase for all civilian federal employees, which was rejected by the House, resulting in a slight reduction in appropriations for civilian salaries. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended funding the pay raise, but neither the part-year continuing resolution nor P.L. 113-6 provided resources for it. The DHS bill's budget breakdown lacks transparency, with varying budgets for different components. Table 4 and Figure 1 display DHS's FY 2013 discretionary budget authority by component. Figure 1 includes adjustments for disaster relief and overseas operations, while Table 4 shows raw numbers. General provisions in the bill include rescissions of prior-year budget authority, impacting net budget authority. The left column in Figure 1 shows discretionary budget authority in P.L. 113-6, while the right column includes adjustments under the BCA. The DHS budget includes adjustments for disaster relief and overseas operations, with funding not solely from discretionary appropriations. Components like TSA and CIS rely on fee income for a significant portion of their budget. Figure 2 compares the Administration's FY2013 budget request with enacted budget, showing discretionary and mandatory appropriations, as well as non-appropriated resources available to DHS. The DHS budget includes adjustments for disaster relief and overseas operations, with funding not solely from discretionary appropriations. Components like TSA and CIS rely on fee income for a significant portion of their budget. The graphic reflecting FY2013 enacted funding includes funding provided through P.L. 113-2, the Disaster Relief Appropriations Act, 2013. Table 5 presents DHS appropriations, as enacted, for FY2003 through FY2013, with amounts not adjusted for inflation or sequestration. The House Appropriations Committee's full committee markup of H.R. 5855 on May 16, 2012, was the second earliest in the history of the DHS appropriations. The House Appropriations Committee's markup of H.R. 5855 on May 16, 2012, was the second earliest in DHS appropriations history. The Senate marked up S. 3216 on May 22, 2012, the earliest ever. P.L. 113-6 was the second-latest enactment of annual appropriations for DHS. Title I of the bill funds management activities, A&O, and OIG. The Administration requested $1,279 million for FY2013, with the House bill proposing $1,020 million and the Senate bill $1,102 million. After cuts, P.L. 113-6 provided $1,086 million for Title I. The enacted amount for Title I in FY2013 was $1,086 million, a decrease from the requested level and below the FY2012 amount. Sequestration further reduced this to $1,026 million, impacting various components within the Department of Homeland Security. The departmental management accounts cover general administrative expenses, including various offices reporting directly to the Secretary. The Administration has requested funding for the consolidation of its headquarters, including the Office of the Chief Financial Officer (OCFO) and the Office of the Chief Information Officer (OCIO). A graphic provides a representation of the discretionary appropriation provided to each element of DHS, showing the FY2013 request compared to the FY2012 enacted appropriations for OSEM, USM, OCFO, and OCIO. The total request for departmental management activities in Title I for FY2012 was $724 million. The Administration requested $134 million for OSEM, with separate line items for three offices. Program changes included funding for the Citizenship and Immigration Services Ombudsman. The Administration also requested $222 million for the USM with several program changes proposed. The Administration requested funding for various offices including OCHCO, OCFO, and OCIO for salaries, expenses, and IT improvements. Specifically, $55 million was requested for OCFO for Financial Systems Modernization, and $313 million for OCIO for Infrastructure and Security Activities, including data center migration for CBP, TSA, and USCIS. The House Appropriations committee recommended reduced funding for management activities under Title I compared to the President's request. The reductions were justified by the committee due to the lack of revenue from unrealized funding proposals and failure to comply with statutory requirements. During floor consideration of appropriations bills on June 6, 2013, several amendments were passed to reduce the budget for departmental management by almost $33 million. The largest amendments included decreasing funds for the Office of the Under Secretary for Management and reallocating them to various agencies such as the Federal Emergency Management Agency and U.S. Customs and Border Protection. During floor consideration of appropriations bills on June 6, 2013, amendments were passed to reduce the budget for departmental management by almost $33 million. The amendments included reallocating funds from the Office of the Under Secretary for Management to agencies like the Federal Emergency Management Agency and U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Additionally, amendments were made to increase funds for Firefighter Assistance Grants by $5 million, leaving the USM with an appropriation of $180 million, $41 million less than requested. Representative Flake proposed reallocating funds from official reception and representation expenses to increase U.S. Customs and Border Protection Salaries and Expenses by $43,000, which was agreed upon by a voice vote. Provisions were also made to withhold $71 million from obligation until all required reports for the FY2014 budget request were received, and a general provision proposed to restrict the use of Coast Guard-operated fixed wing aircraft by the Secretary of DHS. The House Appropriations Committee proposed withholding funds and restricting the use of Coast Guard-operated fixed wing aircraft by key officials until required reports were submitted. Additionally, funding for the Office of General Counsel and OCPO was recommended to be reduced for non-compliance with statutory requirements. Over $124 million would be withheld until all necessary reports for the FY2014 budget request were received. The House Appropriations Committee recommended allocating $242 million for the Office of the Chief Information Officer, with $117 million for salaries and expenses and $125 million for development and acquisition of IT equipment. They also allocated $27 million for Information Technology Services and $55 million for Security Activities. The committee supported the migration of resources to the Department's data centers but did not provide the proposed $65 million due to budget shortfalls mentioned in the President's request. The report emphasized direct communication from relevant components on their areas of responsibility. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended appropriations for various departments, with decreases compared to the President's budget request. The total funding for departmental management would have been $655 million, a decrease of 9.5% from the President's request. The Senate committee report highlighted a programmatic increase for the Office for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, although the recommended budget was still down from FY2012 levels. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended decreased appropriations for departmental management, with OCRCL funding down by $1 million from FY2012 levels. The committee report noted reductions in funding for reception and representation expenses and encouraged filling the historian position. The committee emphasized the need for robust oversight of major acquisitions and security measures to safeguard DHS personnel and facilities. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended appropriations for the Department's critical operational missions, including $35 million for OCHCO and $248 million for OCIO. The funding for OCIO would include $121 million for salaries and expenses, $127 million for technology investments, and $65 million for data center migration. The committee report highlighted the expected savings of nearly $3 billion by 2030 from data center consolidation. The appropriations for OSEM, USM, OCFO, and OCIO were slightly less than the President's request. The Department of Homeland Security's departmental management funding in Title I is $643 million, a decrease of $170 million or 21% from the President's request. Only OCIO experienced a funding reduction due to sequestration. P.L. 113-6 directed the DHS CIO to submit a multi-year investment and management plan for IT projects funded under the CIO or through reimbursable agreements. The Senate's explanatory statement directs the Secretary to provide reports on travel costs, submit a contingency plan for user fee collections, and submit acquisition status reports. DHS is required to report on workforce strategy implementation and justify any insourcing or outsourcing initiatives in the President's annual budget request. The CFO will provide semiannual briefings on financial systems modernization efforts and funding levels for management accounts. The budget reflects spending cuts from FY2012 enacted amounts but does not include the impact of sequestration. The DHS Plan column shows budgetary resources after sequestration, with potential transfers and reprogramming to mitigate the impact. Issues identified by House and Senate Appropriations committees include new revenue assumptions, late submissions of required plans, and conference spending. The Administration's budget proposed separate line items for three offices—the Office of International Affairs (OIA), the Office of State and Local Law Enforcement (SLLE), and the Private Sector Office (PSO)—currently funded under the Office of Policy. The proposal to have these offices report directly to the OSEM was rejected during the legislative process. The House committee recommended establishing an external affairs office to consolidate and streamline functions of various existing offices. The Senate committee report questioned the need for standalone offices within DHS and suggested that functions could be performed adequately within the Office of Policy. The Administration's budget included proposals to increase budgetary resources through aviation security fees, customs fee revenues, and reimbursement agreements with outside parties. The House rejected these proposals, while the Senate included them. The House committee expressed concerns about the budget assumptions and potential shortfalls in revenue. The Committee rejects unrealistic budgeting approaches and emphasizes the need for transparency in budget proposals. It withholds funding due to late submission of required plans and reports. P.L. 113-6 allows CBP to enter into reimbursable agreements for customs services. The House committee expresses concerns about revenue provisions and funding allocation. The Department has been late in responding to Congressional direction and failing to submit required reports on time, leading to a withholding of funding. The Committee emphasizes the importance of investment and expenditure plans for oversight work, criticizing the Department for late, incomplete, or missing submissions. Compliance with statutory requirements is expected. The Committee expects the Department to comply with statutory requirements for reports and plans, noting that many are over three months late. The Senate proposed withholding 59% of budgets until reports are submitted on time, while the House reduced the USM budget by 70%. P.L. 113-6 withholds 20% of budgets until all reports are submitted. The House committee emphasizes oversight of expenditures in the current fiscal climate. The House and Senate bills include provisions for oversight of department spending on travel, conferences, and employee awards programs. Quarterly reports to the DHS OIG on events costing over $20,000 are required, with restrictions on using grants or contracts for unrelated conferences. Compliance with OMB Memorandum M-12-12 is mandated, as per Section 3003 of Division G of P.L. 113-6. The House and Senate bills mandate oversight of department spending on travel, conferences, and employee awards programs. Section 3003 of Division G of P.L. 113-6 requires government-wide reporting on conference costs, with limits on overseas conference attendance. The Department of Homeland Security's headquarters occupies over 7 million square feet in 45 locations in the DC area. The Department of Homeland Security is consolidating its headquarters spread across 22 federal agencies in the National Capital region to improve efficiency. A $3.4 billion master plan with the General Services Administration will create a new DHS headquarters at St Elizabeths in Anacostia, the largest federal office construction since the Pentagon. $1.4 billion will be funded through DHS budget and $2 billion through GSA. $1,366 million has been invested in the project so far, with Phase 1A nearing completion for a new Coast Guard headquarters facility. Not all DHS functions in the DC area will move to the new facility. The Administration has requested $89 million for activities related to the St. Elizabeths DHS headquarters project, including funding for a highway interchange to handle increased traffic. Additionally, $24.5 million was requested for moving the Coast Guard into its new facility in FY2013. No other funding requests for the DHS consolidated headquarters project were included in the budget submission to Congress. The House Appropriations Committee recommended no funding for the highway interchange or any part of the St. Elizabeths project through the management accounts. The bill would have provided the Administration's requested funding for the Coast Guard to move to the new facility, with an additional $10 million through the Coast Guard's construction budget for project support. The Committee recommended no new construction funding for the Departmental Headquarters Consolidation expansion, with funding included in the Coast Guard appropriation for the move to St. Elizabeths. Additional funding under Coast Guard construction was allocated for project completion, site access improvement, and planning adjustments. The Committee supports the Department's efforts to creatively modify or consolidate leases due to delays in constructing a permanent headquarters. $10 million is allocated for Phase 1 of construction to ensure the Coast Guard can move in 2013. The Committee encourages progress updates within 90 days and includes funding for site access improvements. The new DHS headquarters project has faced delays and cost increases, with funding only allocated for the Coast Guard relocation in 2013. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $89 million for necessary road and interchange improvements, but no funding was provided for Phase 2 construction. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $89 million for necessary road and interchange improvements for the DHS headquarters project. The funding remained in the reported version of the legislation, with requirements for expenditure plans and quarterly briefings on consolidation activities. An updated plan is being developed to complete the headquarters consolidation project in smaller, more manageable segments. The Department is working on an updated plan to complete the headquarters consolidation project in smaller, more manageable segments. $29 million is allocated for necessary expenses related to the project, with no reduction through sequestration. Funds from the Analysis and Operations account support the Office of Intelligence and Analysis and the Office of Operations Coordination and Planning. The Analysis and Operations account within the Department of Homeland Security manages intelligence information sharing and operations coordination. The FY2013 budget request was $322 million, with a decrease of $16 million from the previous year. H.R. 5855 proposed $317 million for the account, $4.5 million below the President's request. The House Committee on Appropriations recommended a further decrease of $21 million from the FY2012 level. The House Committee on Appropriations recommended denying proposed increases in executive service salaries and funding for certain elements, while the Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $324 million for the Analysis and Operations account, a decrease from the previous year. The Senate also required DHS's Chief Intelligence Officer to submit an expenditure plan for FY2013. The House Committee on Appropriations rejected increases in executive service salaries and funding for certain elements. The Senate recommended $324 million for the Analysis and Operations account, with a requirement for an expenditure plan for FY2013. P.L. 113-6 allocated $322 million for the account, the same as the President's request and 4.7% lower than FY2012. Sequestration reduced the budget to $306 million, with concerns raised by some Members of Congress about I&A's mission focus. Representative Myrick highlighted the need for clarity in DHS's intelligence mission during a House committee hearing. The Aspen Institute report recommended that DHS focus on specific areas where it has unique strengths and value, rather than duplicating efforts of other agencies. Emphasis should be placed on serving state and local partners, addressing gaps in intelligence coverage. The DHS Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is an independent body that conducts audits and investigations to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse within the department. They requested $144 million in funding, including $2.6 million for audits of states receiving FEMA grant funds for disaster preparedness. The DHS Office of the Inspector General requested $144 million in funding for audits and investigations to prevent waste, fraud, and abuse within the department. The House-passed bill included $109 million for the DHS OIG, with a $10 million reduction due to dissatisfaction with communication on border corruption investigations. The Senate-reported bill allocated $123 million for the DHS OIG, with $24 million coming from FEMA's Disaster Relief Fund for disaster-related audits and investigations. The Senate committee report allocated $121 million in net budget authority for the DHS Office of the Inspector General for FY2013, with an additional $24 million from FEMA's Disaster Relief Fund for investigating corruption and criminal conduct at CBP and ICE. The funding also aimed to complete audits mandated under P.L. 110-53 and grants under the Urban Area Security Initiative grants by August 20, 2014. Sequestration reduced OIG budget authority by $7 million according to the DHS FY2013 expenditure plan. The DHS FY2013 expenditure plan projected a decrease in resources for the OIG by roughly $7 million. The plan required the OIG to conduct various reviews and provide reports to the Appropriations Committees on topics such as budget expenditures, integrity of CBP and ICE officers, non-competitive contracts, and operations of local law enforcement. Additionally, the House directed the OIG to report on compliance with federal laws, conduct TSA screening inspections, assess fraud detection reforms, and review delays in FEMA's public assistance programs. The Senate did not include these provisions in their allocation for the OIG. The Senate did not include provisions for FEMA's public assistance programs in their allocation for the OIG. However, they directed the OIG to review FEMA's application of its rules for awarding public assistance funds for debris removal. The Senate expressed concerns about the OIG's independence and ability to report results in a timely manner. No additional funding was allocated for these new tasks. The statement directs GAO to review the organizational structure of the OIG, how it reports audit results, and if reporting functions comply with independence standards. The OIG has many senior positions filled by acting officials, potentially hindering its duties. The DHS appropriations bill includes funding for CBP, ICE, TSA, USCG, and USSS. The requested budget for FY2013 was $30,759 million, with the House bill proposing $30,946 million and the Senate bill proposing $30,974 million. The DHS appropriations bill for FY2013 provided $31,267 million for Title II, which was reduced to $30,184 million after sequestration. CBP is responsible for security at ports of entry, inspecting people and goods to prevent terrorism. CBP officers and U.S. Border Patrol agents enforce laws and regulations at the border to prevent illegal entries. CBP's programs include Border Security Inspections, Border Security and Control, Air and Marine Interdiction, Automation Modernization, Border Security Fencing, Facilities Management, and immigration and customs user Fee Accounts. Funding for CBP reflects spending cuts relative to FY2012 enacted amounts, but does not include additional cuts required by sequestration. The "DHS Plan" column provides the department's assessment of post-sequester resources. The Administration requested an appropriation of $10,345 million in net budget authority for CBP for FY2013, an increase of $190 million (1.9%) over the enacted FY2012 level of $10,155 million. The total request included $1,626 million in fees, mandatory spending, and trust funds, for a gross budget request of $11,971 million, which is a $320 million (2.8%) increase from the enacted FY2012 level of $11,651 million. Program changes from FY2012 included transferring the U.S. Visitor and Immigrant Status Indicator Technology (US-VISIT) program from NPPD to CBP with a $261.5 million increase, and increases for the Automated Targeting System (ATS) and Office of Intelligence and Investigative Liaison. The Administration requested an appropriation of $10,345 million for CBP for FY2013, with increases for various security-related programs such as the Office of Intelligence and Investigative Liaison, National Targeting Center, Container Security Initiative, and intellectual property rights enforcement. There were also decreases in funding for Office of Air and Marine Interdictions, management and administration staffing, and fleet acquisition and management. The House approved $10,172 in net budget authority for CBP for FY2013, with decreases in various areas such as fleet acquisition, information technology, nonintrusive inspection operations, officer overtime expenses, training expenses, and transportation program. This represents an increase of $17 million from last year's appropriation and a decrease of $173 million from the President's request. The House-passed bill allocated $11,689 in gross budget authority for CBP, with amendments including funding for staffing model completion and communications infrastructure. The Senate Appropriations Committee proposed $10,454 million in net budget authority for CBP for FY2013, an increase of $299 million from last year's appropriation. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act of 2013 provides $10,356 million in net budget authority for CBP for FY2013, with a decrease from the President's request. Sequestration further reduced CBP budget authority by roughly an additional $575 million. Various policy issues related to CBP were discussed during the FY2013 appropriations cycle. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 mandated the implementation of an automated entry and exit data system by the former INS to track foreign visitors' arrival and departure. This system collects biographic and biometric information to verify their identity and is shared with various government agencies to identify potential risks. The entry-exit system has been operational at most U.S. ports of entry since December 2006. The entry-exit system implemented in January 2009 requires most non-citizens entering the US to provide biometric data, but does not collect data from those exiting. The President's FY2013 budget did not include funding for a biometric exit system, focusing instead on an enhanced biographic exit program and a U.S.-Canadian entry-exit system. The enhanced biographic exit program checks passenger manifest data against immigration, criminal, and national security databases to identify overstays and high-priority individuals for follow-up investigations. The Canadian immigration agency shares biometric records of third country nationals entering Canada with DHS, treating them as U.S. exit records. Congress has urged DHS to implement a biometric exit system. The entry-exit system's organizational structure has changed over the years, initially under US-VISIT Program and later proposed under a Screening Coordination Office that was never funded. Funding for the SCO was never appropriated, and US-VISIT became a stand-alone office within DHS in FY2006. In FY2008, US-VISIT was transferred to NPPD. The FY2013 budget proposed to divide US-VISIT's work between CBP and ICE for operational and cost efficiencies. Congress did not fully support the proposed move, with the House bill transferring $73 million to CBP and ICE, and the Senate bill recommending US-VISIT be transferred as a stand-alone appropriation within CBP. US-VISIT Program was replaced entirely under P.L. 113-6. The US-VISIT Program was replaced by the Office of Biometric Identity Management (OBIM) under P.L. 113-6. The President's FY2013 budget requested funding for CBP officers and U.S. Border Patrol agents. Both chambers' budget proposals supported the staffing levels but raised questions about how DHS sets them. The Senate report warned of adverse consequences if DHS preserves high staffing levels during budget tightening. The House report encouraged CBP to consider changes to reduce staffing requirements at POEs, including automation, risk-based targeting, and technology utilization. The House and Senate reports requested more specific staffing and deployment plans for border patrol agents and OFO staffing at Northern Border ports of entry. CBP officer salaries are partially funded by user fees, and efforts are being made to refine the model for forecasting user fee revenues. Border patrol staffing has increased significantly since FY2005, while OFO staffing at POEs has not increased as much despite expanded responsibilities. Some argue that increased enforcement between ports of entry has led to illegal migrants and drug smugglers entering through POEs. Increased OFO staffing is seen as crucial for enhancing security and facilitating legal admissions. With the implementation of sequestration on March 1, 2013, DHS officials warned of potential furloughs and reduced hiring for CBP personnel. Measures to minimize the impact include eliminating performance awards, reducing contracts, and relying on overtime reductions and hiring freezes to avoid employee furloughs. Over 90% of the Border Security and Control budget goes to salaries and benefits. With over 90% of the Border Security and Control budget going to salaries and benefits, CBP frontline staffing may face reduced overtime hours and furlough days. The administration is considering public-private partnerships to enhance services at ports of entry, despite restrictions on CBP providing services on a fee-for-service basis. Section 560 of P.L. 113-6 allows CBP to enter into up to five public-private partnerships in FY2013 for additional services at POEs and new facilities. CBP collects various user fees, including COBRA fees, to fund customs services. These fees reimburse CBP for customs functions and are deposited in the Customs User Fee Account. Congressional interest has been drawn to the collection of COBRA passenger fees without corresponding appropriations. Section 521 of the NAFTA Implementation Act of 1993 and Section 601 of the United States-Colombia Trade Promotion Agreement Implementation Act of 2011 increased fees for passengers entering the US, resulting in significant revenue collection. The funds were directed to the Customs User Fee Account but have not been obligated for customs revenue collection yet. Members of Congress have raised concerns about the appropriation of these funds. Some Members of Congress have raised questions about the disposition of fees collected for customs revenue collection. The House Appropriations Committee directed CBP to report on access to funds identified by GAO and how to eliminate them from the department's books. P.L. 113-6 appropriates $110 million to address a budget shortfall in CBP salaries and directs CBP and OMB to include a means of accessing COBRA fees in future budget requests. DHS uses technology to monitor the Southwest Border for illegal entries. Previous surveillance initiatives have faced criticism for contracting practices and cost overruns. The Obama Administration replaced SBI net with the Arizona Border Technology Plan, focusing on rapid deployment of existing technology. The House and Senate expressed frustration with DHS' implementation of the new border surveillance plan, criticizing CBP for delays in procuring and implementing new surveillance equipment. Both chambers recommended fully funding the President's request for the border surveillance mission but also called for rescinding unobligated balances from the account. P.L. 113-6 includes $73,232,000 in rescissions. CBP also uses manned and unmanned aircraft for surveillance. The President's FY2013 budget request for the Office of Air and Marine Interdiction (OAM) supported 277 aircraft for drug interdiction and border surveillance activities. OAM reported 81,045 flight hours in FY2012 and projected 65,000 hours in FY2013. CBP operated 10 unmanned aerial systems (UAS) as of November 2012, with some Members of Congress supporting their use for border surveillance. However, concerns exist about privacy and cost effectiveness, with a DHS Inspector General report criticizing CBP's UAS program. The President's FY2013 budget request for the Office of Air and Marine Interdiction (OAM) supported 277 aircraft for drug interdiction and border surveillance activities. Both appropriations committees recommended increases to the OAM budget over the President's request, with the House recommending an increase of $82,700,000 and the Senate recommending an increase of $70,997,000. P.L. 113-6 appropriated about $799 million for Air and Marine Operations, directing CBP to restore overall and UAS flight hours to 2011 levels. Cargo bound for the United States is scanned for radiation and inspected before being loaded onto ships. The 100% scanning requirement established by the 9/11 Act has raised concerns about balancing security benefits with costs, such as increased paperwork and longer wait times for importers. Some suggest focusing scanning on high-risk cargo and a random sample of lower-risk cargo to cut costs and make better use of resources. The FY2013 budget request included a $13 million increase to the Container Security Initiative (CSI) and a total of $78 million in proposed increases to the Automated Targeting System for security screening. House and Senate Appropriations Committee reports supported these programs, acknowledging concerns about the costs of implementing a 100% scanning program at foreign ports. ICE focuses on enforcing immigration and customs laws within the United States, developing intelligence to reduce illegal entry and investigating violations. ICE is responsible for locating and removing aliens who have overstayed visas or entered illegally. They also combat terrorist financing, money laundering, and enforce export laws. The FY2013 budget requested $5,332 million for ICE, a decrease from the previous year. The Administration requested $5,644 million in gross budget authority for ICE in FY2013, a decrease of $218 (3.7%) from the FY2012 enacted amount. The budget request included various changes such as increases for the Alternatives to Detention program, video conferencing expansion, and transferring the US-VISIT Program function to ICE. Reductions were made for programs like 287(g), Office of Principle Legal Advisor, detention beds, and Secure Communities. The House-passed H.R. 5855 would have provided $5,474 million in net budget authority for FY2013. ICE's funding for FY2013 saw variations in different proposals. The House-passed H.R. 5855 proposed a total funding authority of $5,786 million, a decrease of $77 million (1.3%) from the FY2012 enacted level. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $5,330 million in net budget authority, a decrease of $2 million (less than 0.1%) from the Administration's request. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act of 2013 provided $5,426 million in net budget authority for ICE, a decrease of $125 million (2.3%) from the previous year. ICE's FY2013 budget saw a decrease in funding compared to the previous year, with a total of $5,738 million in gross budget authority. Sequestration further reduced the budget by $200 million. The agency's allocation of resources for its various activities, including detaining and removing aliens, has been a topic of debate in Congress. ICE's mission includes locating and removing deportable aliens, with a capacity to remove 400,000 aliens a year. There are an estimated 10.8 million unauthorized aliens and 1.9 million aliens who have committed a crime in the US. Legislation directs ICE to prioritize the removal of aliens convicted of a crime based on severity. The Enforcement and Removal Operations (ERO) manages custody of aliens in removal proceedings or ordered removed from the US. Concerns exist about insufficient detention space, leading to decisions on releasing aliens based on space availability rather than individual cases. Some advocate for alternatives to detention for noncriminal alien detainees as a cost-effective and proportional treatment option. Federal government spending involves a multi-step process starting with the enactment of budget authority by Congress, followed by fund obligation and outlays. Budget authority is determined through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation. Budget authority allows federal agencies to spend within limits set by Congress. It can be one-year, multi-year, or no-year, with obligations incurred through personnel, contracts, and services. Outlays are actual funds spent in a fiscal year, which may not always match the budget authority. Multi-year and no-year budget authority can be spent over several years. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. It consists of discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary spending appropriated yearly by Congress and mandatory spending provided in laws other than appropriation acts. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) budget includes both discretionary and mandatory spending. Mandatory entitlement programs, such as Coast Guard retirement pay, must be appropriated each year. Offsetting collections are funds collected by the government to offset discretionary spending. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections.
